body.p: Node Manager is a stand-alone application with an easy to use graphical interface for provisioning local or remote network elements using the equipment craft or an Ethernet interface. The application supports all functions required for fault management, configuration management, user administration, performance management, and security management.
After log-in, users can:

ul.li:
Connect to a single node: See
Connecting to a WaveReady Node on page 5-4

View, monitor and configure a node, with up to 20 windows, panels and dialog boxes open simultaneously. See:
Initial Commissioning of a Node’s Communication Module on page 5-10
Basic Module Configuration on page 6-1, and
Node Manager Overview on page 2-3.

View an Events Log and Alarm Summary for the node. See:
The Alarms Panel on page 2-30
The Events Log Panel on page 2-75
Security Logs and Events on page 4-23
Basic Events Log Operations on page 5-31, and
Viewing the Alarm List on page 7-6.

Manage and configure remote shelves and modules. See:
Configuring for External Shelf Management on page 5-23
External Shelf-Specific Properties Panel Information on page 2-65,
Refreshing the Shelf Inventory on page 5-29, and
Basic Module Configuration on page 6-1.

Create and modify user accounts, giving user access to a single node, or list of nodes. See:
General Description of Node Manager Security on page 4-1
User Accounts on page 4-7, and
User Access on page 4-15

Upgrade node software, on up to five nodes concurrently. See:
Software Download Panels on page 2-28, and
Software Download and Upgrade on page 8-1

Backup and restore configuration data. See:
Back up and Restore Module Configuration on page 2-81.

Collect and view alarms data for a single module, for a node or for a network. See:
The Alarms Panel on page 2-30, and
Alarms and Performance Statistics Management on page 7-1

note.p: The figures shown are examples only. The exact appearance of windows depends on the product selected.
See the applicable Release Notes for supported hardware and software in the current release.

body.p: This chapter describes the WaveReady Node Manager interface; the windows and fields used to configure and manage a node and its modules. General information on using Node Manager is also given here; more detailed instructions on configuring the node, modules and other equipment components is given in other chapters.
This chapter contains the following sections:

li.xref: Node Manager Overview on page 2-3
System Access and Security Windows and Dialogs on page 2-18
Software Download Panels on page 2-28
The Information Panels and Related Windows on page 2-30
The Alarms Panel on page 2-30
The Status and Maintenance Panel on page 2-39
The Inventory Panel on page 2-44
The Properties Panel on page 2-49
The Events Log Panel on page 2-75
The Performance Panel on page 2-78
Back up and Restore Module Configuration on page 2-81
The Chassis Graphic on page 2-84

body.p: Node Manager displays Operation, Administration and Maintenance (OA&M) information in one of three ways:

ul.li: A console view of the node in the Node Manager Main Window,
A real-life graphic representation of a node in the Chassis Graphic, and
Independent dialog boxes displaying one management or configuration function. All three types of windows may be open at the same time.

body.p: All three types of windows may be open at the same time.
Using the Node Manager is a simple three step process.

li.p: First, select the equipment to be viewed or configured from the Explorer panel.
Next, select the appropriate Information panel tab to display the required fields.
Finally, view the equipment properties or configure the equipment from the fields within the Information panel.

body.p: The options displayed by the Information panel tabs and in the Information panel depend on the equipment selected in the Explorer panel.
The Node Manager main window provides a management display of the node and all its installed modules.
Resize the window as required to fit the monitor display. Scroll bars are provided on the bottom and right-hand sides to view any remaining areas.
The window contains these components:

li.xref: Top Menu bar on page 2-4
Tool bar on page 2-6
Explorer panel on page 2-6
Information panel tabs on page 2-10
Tab-specific Information panel on page 2-10
Status bar on page 2-10

body.p: The top menu items and functions are as follows:

ul.li:
File performs the following functions:
Connect to a node,
Disconnect from a node,
Re-connect after a lost connection
Or close all sessions and exit.

View, when an NE is selected:
View alarms,
View a chassis graphic,
List a node inventory,
View the events log,
View the download progress,
View status and maintenance, and
List network elements.

Fault: View network alarms, and when an NE is selected:
Turn off audible alarms on the node,
View alarms,
Configure alarm thresholds,
Inhibit or allow alarms,
Set alarm severity,
View the events log.

Configuration, when an NE is selected, perform the following functions:
View the chassis graphic,
View Node properties,
Access the Status & Maintenance and Inventory windows,
Configure the node properties,
Access the node inventory list,
Refresh the shelf inventory,
Open a TL1 session,
Perform software downloads,
View the software download log,
Perform backups and restore node or module configuration.
When the appropriate module is selected: access the status and maintenance window, manage facility protection and manage the supervisory channel.

Security manages the following security features:
Node user account management,
Session management,
Password management,
Log viewing, and
Log-in banner wording.

Administration, when an NE is selected:
view, clear, or save the Events Logs.
Window: Move between open WRMNM windows.
Help: Launch the WRMNM on-line help or view the About dialog.

body.p: The toolbar contains icons to open, close or restart a session. The toolbar items and functions are as follows:

ul.li:
Connect to Node: Opens the Connect to Node dialog box.
Enter the connection parameters for the new connection.
Click Connect or Cancel.

Disconnect Node: Opens a dialog naming the node and confirming a disconnection request.
Click Disconnect or Cancel.

Exit: Opens a dialog confirming the exit of the application.
Click Yes or No.

note.p: These functions are also available on the File menu.

body.p: The Multi-Node Manager and Node Manager Explorer panels provide a hierarchical explorer view of the network or nudest), expands to reveal the nodes and expands still further to reveal the modules, transponders and ports (if applicable) of each module.This includes transponders installed in a remote shelf without a COM-200 that are managed by the local COM-200 via the supervisory channel (SVC) of a paired transponder in the local shelf.
The nodes displayed in the Explorer panel are color-coded for faster alarm and fault identification:

ul.li: Green = No Alarms
Yellow = Minor Alarms
Orange = Major Alarms
Red = Critical Alarms

body.p: Each node is identified by a user-configured System ID, shelf number, slot number and module name.
Select an element by clicking it in the Explorer panel. The information panel tabs and information panel will display the appropriate information about the selected equipment.

The Multi-Node Manager and Node Manager Explorer panels identify the node, the shelf, the slot in which the module is installed, the transponders and muxponders (if present), the ports and any far-end equipment that is also managed from the local shelf via an SVC connection from a local module. The type of equipment, such as a transponder or port, is also indicated.
The most equipment labels use the following format:
body.msgblock: <system id>-<shelf number>-<slot number>[-<transponder number>]-<port number>[-F-<port number>]
body.p: The exception to this pattern is the WRT-852, which uses the following format:
body.msgblock: <system id>-<shelf number>-<slot number> [-2-F]-<transponder number or port number (1-2)>
body.p: Where:

li.p: <system id> is a user configurable identifier for each NE/node
<shelf number> identifies the shelf in nodes where more than one shelf is managed by a single COM-200.
For the WaveReady 3500 shelf, the <shelf number> will always be “1”.

For the WaveReady 3100 shelf, up to three shelves can be interconnected and managed by a single COM-200. Therefore for the WaveReady 3100 shelf, the <shelf> number will be “1”, “2” or “3”, depending on the configuration.
For external shelf units, such as the WRS-051 (ROADM), the shelves are identified alphabetically, using A through H.
<slot number> refers to the slot in which the module is mounted, (C, 1…13).

In the WaveReady 3500 shelf, slot C (as identified on the faceplate) supports only the COM-200. No other module should be installed in this slot. The TL1 access identifier for this slot is always “C”.

In a locally managed WaveReady 3100 shelf, slot A (as identified on the faceplate) supports a COM-200. The TL1 access identifier for this slot is always “C”. The second slot B (as identified on the faceplate) has the TL1 access identifier “2”.

In a locally managed series of three WaveReady 3100 shelves, shelves 2 and 3 will support WRT-7xx/WRT-8xx/WRA-1xx/WRA-2xx modules in both slots A and B. The TL1 access identifier for these slots will be “1” and “2”. Therefore, the AID naming for modules in three interconnected and fully populated WR3100 shelves will be: 1-C, 1-2; 2-1, 2-2; 3-1, 3-2.
In a remotely managed WaveReady 3100 shelf, or series of interconnected shelves, the slots will be identified as far-end with an “F,” Their full AID will depend on the configuration of the node.
<transponder/muxponder number> is an optional parameter that refers to:
one of the two transponders in an individual WRT-780 module, designated by 1 or 2,
the single transponder of a WRT-852
the single muxponder of a WRM-782
<port number> is an optional parameter that refers to an optical port on a module, and is only required when the TL1 command is directed to a specific port.

[-F[-<port number>]] are both optional parameters that are used to indicate that the command is intended for a far end WRT-740/760 transponder where there is no COM-200 present. The TID of input commands for a far end transponder is the TID of the near-end shelf.

[-2-F] is an optional parameter used to indicate that the command is intended to be transmitted through the network port (2) of a WRT-852 transponder or WRM-782 muxponder. The remainder of the AID then designates whether the command is intended for a single port or the whole transponder/muxponder. The TID of input commands for the far-end port or transponder/muxponder is the TID of the near-end shelf.
li.note: If a COM-200 IS present at the far end, the TID of the far end shelf is used instead.The 'F' portion of this parameter refers to 'far end', while the <port number> is only used if the command relates to a specific optical port on that far end transponder. For example, a valid TL1 AID for a far-end transponder could be “1-2-2-F”, while a valid AID for a specific port on a far-end transponder could be “1-2-2-F-2”.

fig.title: Multi-Node Manager and Node Manager Equipment Labels

body.p: Information panel tabs provide access to application panels that correspond to operations, administration, maintenance, and provisioning (OAM&P) activities.
The Node Manager main window has six tabs for each associated panel:
The functionality of each panel is related to a specific OAM&P category: operations, administration, maintenance, or provisioning activities.
Since these categories do not apply to all equipment all of the time, the tabs are enabled or disabled depending upon the module selected in the Explorer panel.
The information panel is the main element of the Node Manager main window, where most of the configuration and management activities take place.

Once a piece of equipment is selected from the Explorer panel, and the required OAM&P category selected through the appropriate information panel tab, information about the equipment can be viewed or entered in the fields of the information panel.

The status bar includes a real-time active alarms summary banner, and a message area that displays the latest status message and connectivity status. It shows the status of an operation when a request is submitted to the node. Click on the small pop-up arrow on the right hand side of the status bar to display the last 10 messages reported.

The session icon indicates the state of the Node Manager connection with the node. An “X” between the two terminals in the icon indicates that there is not currently a connection, either because of an inactivity time-out or a connection failure.

The alarm banner also displays in real-time the number of alarms by severity against the node being managed by the Node Manager. The banner reflects the alarms for the entire node (including remote modules) rather than for the currently selected equipment. Critical alarm counts are shown in red, major alarms counts are shown in orange, and minor alarm counts are shown in yellow.
The Show area check boxes allow filtering of the alarm list by alarm severity, time filters, and inhibition status. Options for taking snapshots of current alarm information are also included.
The show area contains the following fields and options:

ul.li: Critical check box - Critical alarms appear in the list when the box is checked. By default, this box is checked.
Major check box - Major alarms appear in the list when the box is checked. By default, this box is checked.
Minor check box - Minor alarms appear in the list when the box is checked. By default, this box is checked.

Time Filter check box - Check this box to open a window and filter the list based on when the alarms occurred. Multi-Node Manager only displays alarms that were raised during this time period. When the this box is checked, it indicates that a time filter has been applied to the displayed list.
Time Filter button - Click to open a window and reset the time filter criteria.

Inhibited check box - A status message shows when there are active inhibited alarms that are not currently shown. Check this box to switch from showing the current alarms to show only the inhibited alarms.
Alarm inhibition status is not displayed at the Node level. When Node alarms are inhibited, they are not displayed during a query for all inhibited alarms.

Snapshot button - Click to open a new alarm information window, which contains a snapshot of the current alarm information. To view any subsequent alarm activity, click the Refresh button; this information does not automatically update.
Refresh button - Click to update the alarm information displayed on the panel.
Save As button - Click to open a dialog box and save the current alarm list to a file.

body.p: A chassis graphic window provides a real-time view of the shelf configuration, and direct management of the shelf equipment.
To open a Chassis Graphic and configure equipment:

li.p: Select a node from the Explorer panel
Select Configuration > View Chassis Graphic from the top menu to launch the chassis view.
Right-click a module, the transponder, muxponder or port on a module, or the remote module icon.
On the popup menu, click the menu item that matches the tab named in a step from The Information Panels and Related Windows on page 2-30.
Double-click on a module or port to open the Properties panel for that module or port.

note.p: A menu option is disabled (grayed out) if it is not applicable to the selected equipment.

fig.title: Sample pop-up menu from Chassis Graphic view

topic.title: Remote Shelf and External Shelf Access and Management

section.title: Remote Shelves
section.p: A remote node or module is one installed in a remote shelf; a COM-200 may or may not be present in the remote shelf. There are two basic methods to add and manage a remote node or module.
The Explorer panel will show any remote equipment as part of the node; these remote modules will show an “F” as part of their AID.

section.title: Supervisory Channel
section.p: A remote module may also be managed via the Supervisory Channel (SVC) of a paired module (any of the following: WRT-740 / WRT-760 / WRT-840 / WRT-842-200 / WRT-852) on the shelf with a COM-200 installed. For information about the relationship between the traffic mode of the module and its SVC, see the appropriate module documentation.

section.title: Copper SFPs
section.p: A remote node may be managed via an Ethernet connection from the front plane of the COM-200 using Copper SFPs to convert signals to C/DWDM wavelengths and multiplexing them with line data channels between a pair of WRT-780s. The remote COM-200 will appear as another addressable entity on the network as long as the optical path is available.

section.title: External Shelves and Units
section.p: Some WaveReady units, such as the WRS-051 and WRM-8004, are managed as extensions to a WaveReady shelf-based Network Element (NE) or node where a COM-200 is installed.

section.title: Accessing the WRS-051
section.p: To control the WRS-051, the communication plane of the COM-200 is extended from the confines of the WaveReady shelf to the WRS-051 units by configuring it to operate in EXTERNAL-CONTROL mode. The COM-200 is then connected to the WRS-051 with an Ethernet jumper.

The COM-200 discovery of external units is done automatically, without the need for any further provisioning information. Heartbeats are sent every 10 seconds from the COM-200 to detect any failures in the link.
The discovered WRS-051 is shown as a subtending shelf in the Node Manager Explorer panel. It is managed and configured from that panel in the same manner as the other modules of the node.

Further configuration and management of the WRS-051 optical channels is done through the Wavelength Manager window. To access the Wavelength Manager window, see Accessing the Wavelength Manager window.

context.p: The Wavelength Manager window provides a real-time view of the wavelength configuration, and direct management of the optical channels.
Follow these steps to access the wavelength manager from the Multi-Node Manager main window.

step.cmd: Select an optical channel from the WaveReady Multi-Node Manager Explorer on the left hand side of the Multi-Node Manager window.
Select the Properties tab. The Properties panel displays.
Click the Wavelength Manager Panel button at the lower right hand side of the panel. The Wavelength Manager window displays.

info.p: Hold the cursor over a channel column to display a tool tip for that channel.
For more detailed information about configuring and managing the optical channels, see the WRS-051 Installation and User Guide.
The following figure shows an example of a channel tool tip in the Wavelength Manager window.

context.p: The WRM-8004 can be managed in several ways:

ul.li: Locally using a CLI session and a serial connection to the unit. See the WRM-8004 Installation and User Guide for more information on initiating a serial connection and CLI session.
Remotely through a supervisory channel. See the WRM-8004 Installation and User Guide for more information on initiating a supervisory channel.
Locally or remotely using a TL1 management session initiated through Node Manager.

context.p: A CLI management session with the WRM-8004 can initiated through Node Manager.
Use this procedure to open a CLI management session from the Node Manager interface.
The following items are required for this procedure:

ul.li: A serial or Ethernet connection between the WRM-8004 and the COM-200
The WRM-8004 must have a valid IP address.

context.p: See Avoiding Electrostatic Discharge in the WaveReady Safety Guide included with this document.

step.cmd: Launch Node Manager. The Connect To Node window displays.
Select WRM8004 from the pull-down menu.
Click the appropriate radio button:

substep.cmd: For an Ethernet connection, select the TCP radio button and enter the IP address or DNS name in the Host field.
For a serial connection, select the Serial radio button. Select the Serial Port from the pull-down menu. The supported Baud Rate of 9600 is already selected.

step.cmd: Click OK. A CLI Command Line console displays.

info.p: The following illustrations shows the Connect To Node dialog configured to open a CLI management session with the WRM-8004 via an Ethernet connection with the COM-200 and the CLI Command Line screen.

fig.title: WRMNM Connect To Node Dialog to WRM-8004

step.cmd: Enter the appropriate CLI management commands. See the WaveReady WRM-8004 Installation and User Guide for more information about CLI commands.

topic.title: System Access and Security Windows and Dialogs

body.p: This section provides an overview of the information and operations available through the System Security windows.
These windows are used to perform such tasks as creating and deleting user accounts, set password aging criteria, viewing logged in user accounts and other security related tasks.
Managing and configuring System Security settings is described in more detail in Security on page 4-1
The available System Security windows include:

li.xref: NE User Management window on page 2-19
The Add/Modify NE User Account window on page 2-20
The Change Password for User window on page 2-22
The Log-in Banner Configuration window on page 2-23
The Active Sessions window on page 2-25
The Security Log window on page 2-26

body.p: Use this window to manage user accounts by setting enabling or disabling an account, assigning security privilege levels, set password aging and logins, and add and delete users.
This section covers the following topics:

li.xref: Accessing the NE User Management window on page 2-19
NE User Management window components on page 2-19
Related tasks on page 2-20

topic.title: Accessing the NE User Management window

body.p: To access the NE User Management window, select Security > Manage Node Users from the top menu.
The following fields and options are displayed on the NE User Management window:

ul.li: Name - Shows the username assigned to the account.
Enabled - Shows whether an account is enabled (true) or disabled (false).
Sec - Shows the Security Administration privilege level assigned to the account.
Prov - Shows the Provisioning privilege level assigned to the account.
Perf - Shows the Performance privilege level assigned to the account.
Main - Shows the Maintenance privilege level assigned to the account.
Test - Shows the Test Access privilege level assigned to the account.
PAGE - Shows the password aging in days.
PCNN - Shows the number of logins that an aged password can be used before a new one is required.
Add User button - Click to open the Add NE User Account window.
Modify User button - Click to open the Modify NE User Account window to modify the selected user account.
Delete User button - Click to delete the selected user. This button is not enabled if the account selected for deletion is the account attempting to make the deletion.
Refresh button - Click to refresh the information displayed in the window.
Close button - Click to close the window.

body.p: Use the NE User Management window to do the following tasks:

li.xref: Creating a New User Account on page 4-7
Setting the Password Aging Criteria on page 4-17
Deleting a User Account on page 4-13

topic.title: The Add/Modify NE User Account window

body.p: Use this window to assign attributes to a new user account, or to edit existing attributes.
This section covers the following topics:

li.xref: Accessing the Add/Modify NE User Account Window on page 2-20
The Add/Modify NE User Account window components on page 2-21
Related tasks on page 2-22

topic.title: Accessing the Add/Modify NE User Account Window

body.p: Access the Add/Modify NE User Account window by clicking the Add User or Modify User in the NE User Management window.

topic.title: The Add/Modify NE User Account window components

fig.title: Sample Add NE User Account window

body.p: The following fields and options are displayed in the Add/Modify NE User Account window:

ul.li: User ID - Enter, or edit the username for the account here.
Password - Display only. Reminder to assign a password to the account.

Privileges - Drop-down arrows in each field select the access privilege level to assign to the selected category. Access privileges are used to limit the scope of the actions the user is permitted to perform on the node, or the system. Default privilege level is “5”.

There is a field for each of the following functional categories:
Sec (Security Administration)
Prov (Provisioning)
Perf (Performance Monitoring)
Main (Maintenance)
Test (Test Access)
Edit Password button - Opens a window to create a default password for a new account, or to modify the password for an existing account.
Enable button - Enables the selected account.
Disable button - Disables the selected account.
Basic / Advanced button - Show or hides advanced attributes in the window. The text on this button depends on the currently displayed fields on the screen.
Apply button - Submits the information to the node.
Close button - Closes the window.

body.p: The following fields and options are displayed as Advanced Attributes in the Add/Modify NE User Account window:

ul.li: Age password after <nn> days - (Advanced attribute only) Enter the number of consecutive days during which the password is valid. Valid range is 1-999. The password expires when the number of days is reached.
Enable aged password within <nn> logins of aging - (Advanced attribute only) Enter the number of times the user can log in after the password expires (a grace period). Valid range is 1-999

body.p: Use the Add/Modify NE User Account window to do the following tasks:

li.xref: Assigning Privilege Levels on page 4-18
Modifying a User Account on page 4-12

topic.title: The Change Password for User window

body.p: Use this window to change a password.
This section covers the following topics:

li.xref: Accessing the Change Password for User Window on page 2-22
The Change Password for User Window components on page 2-23
Related tasks on page 2-23

topic.title: Accessing the Change Password for User Window

body.p: To access the Change Password for User window, select Security > Change Password from the top menu.

topic.title: The Change Password for User Window components

fig.title: Sample Change Password for User window

body.p: The following fields and options are displayed on the Change Password for User window:

ul.li: Old Password - Enter the current password.
New Password - Enter a new password.
Confirm password - Enter a new password again. Node Manager uses this field to validate the new password.
Set Password button - Click to submit the new password.

Cancel button - Behavior depends on the situation. For a first-time log-in, a dialog box opens to confirm the action before closing the WaveReady Node Manager application. This is done because new users must change their passwords. If this is not a first-time log-in, click to close the window.

body.p: Use the Change Password for User window to do the following tasks:

li.xref: Changing a Password on page 4-16

body.p: Use this window to modify the message that displays when users log in to a node from a TL1 shell.
This section covers the following topics:

li.xref: Accessing the Login Banner Configuration Window on page 2-24
The Login Banner Configuration window components on page 2-24
Related tasks on page 2-25

topic.title: Accessing the Login Banner Configuration Window

body.p: To access the Login Banner Configuration window, select Security > Configure Login Banner from the top menu.

topic.title: The Login Banner Configuration window components

body.p: The following fields and options are displayed on the Login Banner Configuration window:

ul.li:
Login Message - Editable field showing the text of the current login banner.
The maximum size of the Login banner is 1024 characters.
Set Message button - Click to change the text of the log-in message to the text currently entered in the Login Message field.
Refresh button - Click to refresh the information displayed in the window.
Close button - Click to close the window.

body.p: Use the Login Banner Configuration window to do these tasks:

li.xref: Configuring the Login Banner on page 4-20

body.p: Use this window to view a list of all the users currently logged in to the node. The SUPERUSER account can use this window to terminate other user's sessions. See Limits on Account Usage on page 1-3 for more information about using the SUPERUSER account.
This section covers the following topics.:

li.xref: Accessing the Active Sessions Window on page 2-25
The Active Sessions window components on page 2-25
Related tasks on page 2-26

body.p: To access the Active Sessions window, select Security > View Active Sessions from the top menu.
The following fields and options are displayed on the Active Sessions window:

ul.li: User Name - Shows the username of each account currently logged in to the node. Used to select the sessions to terminate.
# Sessions - Shows the total numbers of sessions that the user is running.
Terminate button - Click to terminate all of the sessions for selected user. The button is not enabled if SUPERUSER or self is selected.
Refresh button - Click to refresh the information displayed in the window.
Close button - Click to close the window.

body.p: Use the Active Sessions window to do the following tasks:

li.xref: Terminating User Sessions on page 4-22

body.p: Use this window to view or save the log of security events raised on the node.
This section covers the following topics.:

li.xref: Accessing the Security Log Window on page 2-26
The Security Log window components on page 2-27
Related tasks on page 2-27

body.p: To access the Security Log window, select Security > View Log from the top menu.
The following fields and options are displayed on the Security Log window:

ul.li: Date column - Display only. Shows the date and time that the event was triggered.
User/Log column - Display only. Shows information about the user account associated with the alarm.
Severity column - Display only. Shows the severity of the alarm, or “Not Reported” if the event is not reported.
Description column - Display only. Shows the description associated with the event.
Event column - Display only. Shows the event name associated with the event
Type column - Display only. Shows the event type associated with the event
Refresh button - Click to refresh the information displayed in the window.
Save As button - Click to save the contents of the log to a file.
Close button - Click to close the window.

body.p: Use the Security Log window to do the following tasks:

li.xref: Viewing the Security Log on page 4-24
Saving the Security Log on page 4-25

body.p: JDSU releases periodic upgrades to WaveReady equipment software and recommends that, in order to ensure optimal operation of their equipment and networks, users download new software as it becomes available.
Equipment software upgrades are done at the Node level in Multi-Node Manager.
This section provides an overview of using the Software Download window to upgrade and synchronize software loads for the active and standby banks on the node or modules in the node.

note.p: The LightAmp, BrightAmp and LP-530 modules do not support software upgrades.
Software Downloads and Upgrades are covered in more detail in Software Download and Upgrade on page 8-1.

body.p: This section covers the following topics:

li.xref: Accessing the Software Download Window on page 2-28
The Software Download window components on page 2-29
Related tasks on page 2-30

body.p: To access the Software Download window, select Configuration > Download Software from the top menu.
The following fields and options are displayed in the Software Download window:

ul.li: Module List panel -View software versions and view the progress of an upgrade.
Software Releases panel - View and select a software release.
Node Download button - Download software updates to the node. This button is not active until a software release is selected in the Software Releases panel
Node Synchronize button - Synchronize the software on the standby bank with the active bank for the node.
Change Location button - Click to browse and locate the appropriate software release for a download. Verify the release prior to initiating the download is recommended.
Refresh button - Click to refresh the information displayed in the window.
Close button - Click to close the window.

body.p: Use the Software Download window to do these tasks:

li.xref: Upgrade Prerequisites on page 8-2
Verifying Node Software Before Download on page 8-5
Downloading Software to a Node on page 8-9
Synchronizing Software Loads on page 8-14

topic.title: The Information Panels and Related Windows

body.p: This section provides an overview of the information available in each information panel. Managing and configuring equipment using these information panels will be described in more detail in later chapters.
The information panels are selected by clicking one of the tabs along the top of the Node Manager main window. The tabs access:

li.xref: The Alarms Panel on page 2-30
The Status and Maintenance Panel on page 2-39
The Inventory Panel on page 2-44
The Properties Panel on page 2-49
The Events Log Panel on page 2-75
The Performance Panel on page 2-77

body.p: These panels display two types of fields: display only fields that display information about the selected equipment and active fields for entering configuration information.

This panel retrieves and displays a list of active alarms for selected equipment, and is available for nodes, modules, and ports. Use this panel to view and troubleshoot faults that occur in the node. Use buttons and boxes in this panel to access various alarm management windows to filter or inhibit alarms and configure alarm severity and thresholds.
body.note: Detailed procedures to configure and manage alarms are described in Alarms and Performance Statistics Management on page 7-1
body.p: This section includes information about:

li.xref: Accessing the Alarms Panel or Window on page 2-31
The Alarms Panel on page 2-31
Alarm Counts area on page 2-32
Alarm List area on page 2-33
Show area on page 2-33
Alarm Details area on page 2-34
The Chassis Graphic Alarms Window on page 2-35
Modifying the Alarms Panel on page 2-34
Other Alarms Management Windows on page 2-35

topic.title: Accessing the Alarms Panel or Window

body.p: Select a node component, then access the Alarms panel by:

ul.li: From the main window, clicking the Alarms tab
From the top menu, selecting Fault > View Alarms
From the chassis graphic, right-clicking on a module or a port and selecting Alarms.

body.p: The Alarms panel contains these main components:
This area shows a summary of the alarms currently active on the selected equipment. Alarms are grouped according to the severity: critical, major, and minor.
The counts area contains the following fields:

ul.li: Critical - Display only. Highlighted with a red background, this field shows the total number of critical alarms raised by the selected equipment.
Major - Display only. Highlighted with an orange background, this field shows the total number of major alarms raised by the selected equipment.
Minor - Display only. Highlighted with a yellow background, this field shows the total number of minor alarms raised by the selected equipment.
Total - Display only. Shows the total number of alarms raised by the selected equipment.

body.p: This area displays all the non-inhibited alarms currently active on the selected equipment.

note.p: Rearrange the columns by dragging a column heading bar to a new position. Sort the list by ascending or descending order by clicking on the column header.

body.p: The alarm list area contains these fields:

ul.li: Time - Display only. Shows the timestamp indicating when the alarm occurred. All the modules in the node update their clocks from the clock in the communication module.
Resource - Display only. Shows the location (shelf, slot number, port, and in the case of remote modules, the module or port at the far-end) of the equipment that raised the selected alarm.

Type - Display only. Shows the type of condition that caused the alarm. For a complete list of alarms and events, see Security Event Descriptions on page 4-26and Non-Security Type Alarm and Event Descriptions on page 7-22.
Severity - Display only. Shows the severity of the alarm.

Reason - Display only. Shows a brief text explanation for the probable cause of the alarm. See Security Event Descriptions on page 4-26and Non-Security Type Alarm and Event Descriptions on page 7-22, for a complete list of possible reasons.

body.p: The Show area check boxes allow filtering of the alarm list by alarm severity, time filters, and inhibition status. Options for taking snapshots of current alarm information are also included.
The show area contains the following fields and options:

ul.li: Critical check box - Critical alarms appear in the list when the box is checked. By default, this box is checked.
Major check box - Major alarms appear in the list when the box is checked. By default, this box is checked.
Minor check box - Minor alarms appear in the list when the box is checked. By default, this box is checked.

Time Filter check box - Check this box to open a window and filter the list based on when the alarms occurred. Node Manager only displays alarms that were raised during this time period. When the this box is checked, it indicates that a time filter has been applied to the displayed list.
Time Filter button - Click to open a window and reset the time filter criteria.

Inhibited check box - A status message shows when there are active inhibited alarms that are not currently shown. Check this box to switch from showing the current alarms to show only the inhibited alarms.
Alarm inhibition status is not displayed at the Node level. When Node alarms are inhibited, they are not displayed during a query for all inhibited alarms.

Snapshot button - Click to open a new alarm information window, which contains a snapshot of the current alarm information. To view any subsequent alarm activity, click the Refresh button; this information does not automatically update.
Refresh button - Click to update the information displayed on the panel.
Save As button - Click to open a dialog box and save the current alarm list to a file.

body.p: This area shows additional information about the alarm currently selected (highlighted). Click an alarm in the list to select and display details about the alarm.
The Alarm Details area contains these fields:

ul.li: Resource Type - Display only. Shows the type of equipment (module or port) that raised the selected alarm.
Resource Location - Display only. Shows the location (shelf, slot number, port, and in the case of paired modules, the module or port at the far-end) of the equipment that raised the selected alarm.
Time - Display only. Shows the time at which the selected alarm occurred.
Condition Type - Display only. Shows the condition associated with the selected alarm.
Reason - Display only. Shows a brief text description of the probable cause of the selected alarm.
Severity - Display only. Shows the severity of the selected alarm.
Service Affecting - Display only. Shows if the condition causing the selected alarm is affecting the signal transmission.

body.p: Modify the Alarms panel by:

ul.li: Remove alarms from the list by un-checking alarm severity check boxes. For example, limit the list to critical alarms only, by un-checking the major and minor alarms severity check boxes
Rearrange the columns by dragging a column heading bar to a new position.
Sort the list by ascending or descending order by clicking on the column header.

body.p: Use the Alarms panel to do these tasks:

li.xref: Viewing the Alarm List on page 7-6
Filtering the Alarm List on page 7-7
Refreshing the Alarm List on page 7-9
Saving the Alarm List on page 7-9

body.p: The Alarms window contains the same components as the The Alarms Panel on page 2-31, with the addition of a Close button at the bottom right hand corner.
Access the Chassis Graphic Alarms window by:

li.p: Select a node from the Explorer panel.
Select View > Chassis Graphic to display the chassis graphic for the node.
Right-click on a module graphic in the chassis graphic and select Alarms from the pop-up menu.

body.p: Use the buttons and display area in this window to review the alarms associated with the node element chosen, then return to the Chassis Graphic by clicking the Close button.
Node Manager provides four other windows to view, manage and configure alarm settings. These windows are:

li.xref: Alarms Time Filter window on page 2-35
Alarm Inhibition window on page 2-36
Alarm Severity window on page 2-37
Alarm Thresholds window on page 2-38

body.p: Use this window to view alarms in the Alarms panel for a specified time period. See Filtering the Alarm List on page 7-7

To access the Alarms Time Filter window from the Alarms panel, check the Time Filter check box (if no time filter is currently in effect), or click the Time Filter button (if a time filter is currently in effect).
The following fields and options are displayed on the Alarms Time Filter window:

ul.li: Start radio button and drop down list - Click and scroll to choose a start time for the specified time period.
End drop down list - Scroll to choose an end time for the specified time period.
Last <nn> hour(s) radio button and drop down list - Click and scroll to choose the last number of hours for which to view alarms.
OK button - Click to apply the time filter to the list. The Alarms panel automatically refreshes after the Alarms Time Filter window closes.
Cancel button - Click to close the window without setting a time filter.

body.p: Use this window to inhibit or allow alarms at the node, module, or port level. See Inhibiting or Allowing Alarms on page 7-5.

note.p: Alarm inhibition status is not displayed at the Node level. When Node alarms are inhibited, they are not displayed during a query for all inhibited alarms.

body.p: To access the Alarm Inhibition window, select the equipment and then select Fault > Inhibit/Allow Alarms from the top menu.
The following fields and options are displayed on the Alarm Inhibition window:

ul.li: Condition column - Display only. Shows the condition associated with the alarm.
Description column - Display only. Shows the description associated with the alarm.
Inhibited column - Shows the current inhibition status of the alarm for modules and ports. Click each column entry to change the inhibition status of the alarm.
Allow All button - Click to allow all alarms shown in the list.
Inhibit All button - Click to inhibit all alarms shown in the list.
Apply button - Click to apply changes to individually changed alarms (changed using the Inhibited column drop-down menu).
Refresh button - Click to refresh the information displayed in the window.
Close button - Click to close the window.

note.p: Sort the list by ascending or descending order by clicking on the column header.

body.p: Use this window to set the severity condition for alarms associated with a specific port or module, or all ports or modules of the same type in a node. See Setting Alarm Severity for Modules or Ports on page 7-1.
To access the Alarm Inhibition window, select the equipment and then select Fault > Set Alarm Severity from the top menu.
The following fields and options are displayed on the Alarm Severity window:

ul.li: Condition column - Display only. Shows the condition associated with the alarm.
Description column - Display only. Shows the description associated with the alarm.
Severity column - Shows the current severity of the alarm. Click each column entry to access a pull-down menu to change the severity of the alarm.
Apply to All button - Click to apply the current severity settings to modules of the same type in the node.
Apply button - Click to apply changes to individually changed alarms (changed using the Severity column drop-down menu)
Refresh button - Click to refresh the information displayed in the window.
Close button - Click to close the window.

body.p: Use the Alarm Thresholds window to configure the alarm temperature thresholds for selected equipment. See Configuring Alarm Temperature Thresholds on page 7-3
To access the Alarm Thresholds window, select the equipment and then select Fault > Configure Alarm Thresholds from the top menu.
The following fields and options are displayed on the Alarm Thresholds window:

ul.li: Minimum Case Temperature - Minimum case temperature, in degrees C.
Minimum Case Temperature Hysteresis - Minimum case temperature hysteresis, in degrees C
Maximum Case Temperature - Maximum case temperature, in degrees C.
Maximum Case Temperature Hysteresis - Maximum case temperature hysteresis, in degrees C.
Apply button - Click to apply changes to these thresholds.
Refresh button - Click to refresh the information displayed in the window.
Close button - Click to close the window.

body.p: This panel retrieves and displays information about the operating state of selected equipment. This information is available for modules, transponders and ports. Use this panel to view or change the operating state of the selected equipment and to execute maintenance functions.
The fields displayed on the panel depend on the type of equipment selected.

note.p: Detailed procedures to configure and manage operating states are described in Chapter 5: Module Configuration and Management

body.p: This section includes information about:

li.xref: Accessing the Status and Maintenance Panel or Window on page 2-40
The Status and Maintenance Panel on page 2-41
The Chassis Graphic Status and Maintenance Window on page 2-44
Status and Maintenance Panel Buttons on page 2-43

topic.title: Accessing the Status and Maintenance Panel or Window

body.p: After selecting the appropriate equipment from the Explorer panel, use any of these methods to access the Status & Maintenance panel:

ul.li: Click the Status & Maintenance tab at the top of the Information panel
From the top menu, select Configuration > View Status & Maintenance
Right-click the image of the appropriate equipment from the Chassis Graphic window and select Status & Maintenance from the pop-up menu

body.p: The Status and Maintenance panel contains these components:
The fields displayed depend on the equipment selected. Some or all of these fields are displayed, depending on the type of equipment selected.

ul.li: Primary State: Display only. Indicates whether the module or port is In Service or Out Of Service. Primary state changes are triggered by these events:
Occurrence or clearing of a traffic-affecting fault
Operator command to transition to or from a maintenance state

Primary State Qualifier: Display only. Provides additional information about the primary state of the selected equipment. When the equipment is In Service, the field shows if the equipment state is:
Normal or
Abnormal.

When a module is Out Of Service, the field indicates if the module is out-of-service as the result of a user action, a fault in the equipment, or the result of some event. These qualifiers are associated with the out-of-service state:
Autonomous
Management
Autonomous-and-Management
Management-and-Abnormal

Secondary State: Display only. Shows additional information about the primary and primary state qualifiers. For example, the secondary state can indicate the type of, and/or the reason, for the user action or the event that occurred. These are the possible secondary states:
No Backup
Standby-Hot
Standby Inhibited
Working
Loopback
Facility Failure - An LOS or LOL condition exists
Fault - SFP failure
Unequipped - SFP missing
Protocol Violation
Power
Supporting Entity Outage

note.p: It is possible for the equipment to have more than one secondary state at a time.

ul.li: Laser Disabled: Display only. Indicates if the laser associated with the selected equipment is enabled or disabled. Appears only when the network port for the applicable equipment including WRT-740, WRT-760, LightAmp and BrightAmp is selected.
Protection Switch: Display only. Shows the protection status of selected port.

body.p: The buttons displayed depend on the equipment selected. Some or all of these buttons are displayed, depending on the type of equipment selected:

ul.li: Remove / Restore button - Click to change the operating state of the equipment. The label that appears on this button depends on the current state of the equipment. When the equipment is In Service, the label is Remove. When the port is Out Of Service, the label is Restore.
Restart button - Click to perform a hardware reset of the selected module.

Loopback / Release Loopback button - Click to start or release a loopback on the selected port. The label that appears on this button depends on the state of the loopback. If the port is in service, this button is disabled. If no loopback is in progress, the button label reads Loopback. If a loopback is in progress, the label reads Release Loopback.
Refresh button - Click to update the information displayed on the panel.

Enable/Disable Laser button - Appears only when the network port is selected. Click to enable or disable the laser on the selected port. The label that appears on this button depends on the current state of the laser. If the laser is on, the label is Disable Laser. If the laser is off, the label is Enable Laser. If the port is not in service, the button is disabled.
Protection Switch button - Use this button to select or clear a protection switch on the selected WRT760 network port.

note.p: To maintain supervisory channel connectivity, a laser on a remote module cannot be disabled.

body.p: Use the Status & Maintenance panel to do the following tasks:

li.xref: Changing a Module's State on page 6-10
Changing a Port's State on page 6-12
Enabling or Disabling the Network Port Laser on page 6-17
Setting a WRT-7xx/8xx/WRM-782 Loopback on page 6-14
Releasing a WRT-7xx/8xx/WRM-782 Loopback on page 6-16
Verifying Equipment Operating State on page 6-9
Performing a WRT-760 Manual Switch Over on page 6-42
Clearing a WRT-760 Protection Switch on page 6-43

topic.title: The Chassis Graphic Status and Maintenance Window

body.p: The Status and Maintenance window contains the same components as the The Status and Maintenance Panel on page 2-41, with the addition of a Close button at the bottom right hand corner.
Access the Chassis Graphic Status and Maintenance window by:

li.p: Select a node from the Explorer panel.
Select View > Chassis Graphic to display the chassis graphic for the node.
Right-click on an equipment graphic (such as a module or port) in the chassis graphic and select Status and Maintenance from the pop-up menu.

body.p: Use the buttons and display area in this window to review the status of the node element selected, remove it from service or perform a restart, then return to the Chassis Graphic by clicking the Close button.
This panel retrieves and displays hardware and software information about selected equipment. This information is available for nodes and modules.
The fields displayed on the panel depend on the type of equipment selected.
This section includes information about:

li.xref: Accessing the Inventory Panel or Window on page 2-44
The Inventory Panel on page 2-45
The Chassis Graphic Inventory Window on page 2-46
Inventory Panel Buttons on page 2-46

topic.title: Accessing the Inventory Panel or Window

body.p: After selecting a node or module, use any of these methods to access the Inventory panel:

ul.li: Click the Inventory tab at the top of the Information panel.
Select the Configuration menu and then select View Inventory Information.
Right-click the Chassis Graphic and select Status & Maintenance from the pop-up menu.

body.p: The Inventory panel contains these components:
Some or all of the following fields are displayed in the Inventory panel, depending on the type of equipment selected:

ul.li: Shelf Type - Display only. Identifies the type of shelf in which the COM-200 is mounted.
Hardware Revision - Display only. Shows the shelf hardware revision number.
EEPROM Version - Display only. Shows the current version of the electronically erasable programmable read only memory (EEPROM) device on the shelf backplane.
Backplane Serial Number - Display only. Shows the serial number that identifies this specific shelf.
Marketing Part Number - Display only. Shows the marketing number of the selected equipment.
MAC Address - Display only. Shows the address for the device as it is identified at the media access control (MAC) layer in the network architecture.
Module Type - Display only. Shows the type of module selected.
Marketing Part Number - Display only. Shows the marketing part number of the selected equipment
Manufacturing Part Number - Display only. Shows the manufacturing part number of the selected equipment.
Serial Number - Display only. Shows the serial number of the selected equipment.
Bootrom Software Revision - Display only. Shows the boot software revision of the selected equipment.
Application Software Revision - Display only. Shows the application software revision of the selected equipment.
EDFA Software Revision - Display only. Shows the Erbium Doped Fiber Amplifier (EDFA) software revision of the selected equipment.
Hardware Revision - Display only. Shows the hardware revision of the selected equipment.
CLEI - Display Only. Common Language Equipment Identifier.
WaveReady Node Manager - Display only. Shows the name of the WaveReady Node Manager.

body.p: The following buttons are displayed in the Inventory panel:

ul.li: Refresh button - Click to update the information displayed on the panel.

body.p: Use the Inventory panel to do the following tasks:

li.xref: Verifying Equipment Inventory Information on page 6-6

body.p: The Inventory window contains the same components as the The Inventory Panel on page 2-45, with the addition of a Close button at the bottom right hand corner.
Access the Chassis Graphic Status and Maintenance window by:

li.p: Select a node from the Explorer panel.
Select View > Chassis Graphic to display the chassis graphic for the node.
Right-click on an equipment graphic (such as a module or port) in the chassis graphic and select Status and Maintenance from the pop-up menu.

body.p: Use the buttons and display area in this window to review the inventory information, then return to the Chassis Graphic by clicking the Close button.
Node Manager provides two other windows to view inventory and network elements lists. These windows are:

li.xref: Node Inventory List window on page 2-47
Network Elements List window on page 2-48

body.p: Use this window to view inventory information about all the modules in a node. See Verifying Equipment Inventory Information on page 6-6
To access the Node Inventory List window, select Configuration > List Node Inventory or View > List Node Inventory from the top menu.

The following columns and buttons are displayed on the Node Inventory List window. Rearrange the columns by dragging a column heading bar to a new position. Sort the list by ascending or descending order by clicking on the column header.

ul.li: Location column - Display only. Shows the shelf number and slot number of the modules managed by the COM-200.
Type column - Display only. Shows the type of module managed by the COM-200.
Serial # column - Display only. The serial number of the module.
H/W Revision column - Display only. The hardware revision of the module.
S/W Revision column - Display only. The software revision of the module.
Boot Revision column - Display only. The software boot revision number.
Refresh button - Click to refresh the information displayed in the window.
Save As button - Click to save a copy of the current inventory information.
Close button - Click to close the window.

body.p: Use this window to view information about all of the network elements visible to the node.
To access the Network Elements List window, select Configuration > List Network Elements or View > List Network Elements from the top menu.
The following fields and options are displayed on the Network Elements List window:

ul.li: System Identifier column - Display only. Shows the system ID assigned to each node.
Number of Hops column - Display only. Shows the number of supervisory links a message must traverse in order to reach the remote WRT-740/WRT-760/WRT-840/WRT-842/WRT-852.
Refresh button - Click to refresh the information displayed in the window.
Close button - Click to close the window.

body.p: This panel retrieves and displays the configuration and operating properties information about selected equipment. This information is available for nodes, modules, transponders and ports. Use the Properties panel to view or reconfigure the operating properties of selected equipment.
The fields displayed on the panel depend on the type of equipment selected. This section includes information about:

li.xref: Accessing the Properties Panel or Window on page 2-50
Node Specific Properties Panel Information on page 2-50
IPv6 Addressing on page 2-54
Equipment Specific Properties Panel Information. on page 2-56
Module-Specific Properties Panel Fields on page 2-57
Transponder/Muxponder-Specific Properties Panel Fields on page 2-60
Port-Specific Properties Panel Fields on page 2-61
External Shelf-Specific Properties Panel Information on page 2-65
Other Properties Management windows on page 2-70
The Wavelength Management Window on page 2-67
The Chassis Graphic Properties Window on page 2-74

topic.title: Accessing the Properties Panel or Window

body.p: After selecting a node or module from the Explorer panel, access the Properties panel in these ways:

ul.li: Click the Properties tab in the main window.
Select the Configuration menu and then select Node Properties or Configure Properties.
Right-click the Chassis graphic and select Properties from the pop-up menu.

body.p: The Properties panel information fields depend on the type of equipment selected.
These fields appear on the Properties panel when a node is selected:

ul.li: System ID - Display only. Shows the system identifier for the selected node. Multi-Node Manager uses this identifier to direct commands to a specific COM-200, and to identify the source of messages it receives. To set the System ID, click the Set the System ID button on the lower right hand corner of the panel.

IPv4 IP Address* - Shows, or use to enter an globally accessible IP address for the selected node. WaveReady Multi-Node Manager supports dual-stack addressing for the node IP address. The COM-200 must be reset in order for a change in this field to take effect.
IPv4 Addressing: Valid format for an IPv4 address is nnn.nnn.nnn.nnn, where nnn is an integer between 0 and 255.
IPv6 Addressing: IPv6 address fields are equipped with first level IPv6 validation patterns. First level validation discards irrelevant input, reading only the input that is applicable to form a valid IPv6 address, for example: A-F or a-f and 0-9 with: (colon) and. (dot) characters.

Ipv4 Subnet Mask or Prefix* - Shows, or use to enter the subnet mask or prefix for the selected node. WaveReady Multi-Node Manager supports dual-stack addressing for the node IP subnet mask or prefix. The COM-200 must be reset for a change in this field to take effect.
IPv4 Subnet Mask: Valid format for an IPv4 mask is nnn.nnn.nnn.nnn, where nnn is an integer between 0 and 255, except for the integer in the last position, which must be less than 255.

IPv4 Gateway IP Address* - WaveReady Multi-Node Manager supports dual-stack addressing for the node IP gateway IP address. The COM-200 must be reset in order for a change in this field to take effect.
IPv4 Addressing: Valid format for an IPv4 address is nnn.nnn.nnn.nnn, where nnn is an integer between 0 and 255.
NTP Client- When enabled, this option enables the COM-200 NTP service to periodically query the provisioned NTP server to update the system and real-time clock.

NTP Server 1 and 2 - Configure an IP address for one or two NTP servers. At least one IP address must be configured to start the NTP service. WaveReady Multi-Node Manager supports dual-stack addressing for the NTP Server.
IPv4 Addressing: Valid format for an IPv4 address is nnn.nnn.nnn.nnn, where nnn is an integer between 0 and 255.

SNMP Agent* - Determines if the selected node can communicate using the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP). The COM-200 must be reset in order for a change in this field to take effect.
Disabled radio button - Select to prevent the node from communicating using SNMP.
Enabled radio button - Select to allow the node to communicate using SNMP.

body.note: SNMP is not supported for all WaveReady systems. See the applicable Release Notes for supported hardware and software.

ul.li:
SNMP Traps - Determines if the selected node can broadcast SNMP messages to an SNMP management station in a different network.
Disabled radio button - Select to prevent the node from broadcasting SNMP messages to an SNMP management station.
Enabled radio button - Select to allow the node to broadcast SNMP messages to an SNMP management station.

SNMP Trap Destination 1/ 2/ 3/ 4 - Use these fields to enter the IP addresses of the SNMP management station(s) to which the Multi-Node Manager can broadcast SNMP messages. WaveReady Multi-Node Manager supports dual-stack addressing for the SNMP Trap Destinations. For this function to operate, “Enabled” must be selected in the SNMP Traps field.
IPv4 Addressing: Valid format for an IPv4 address is nnn.nnn.nnn.nnn, where nnn is an integer between 0 and 255.
IPv6 Addressing: IPv6 address fields are equipped with first level IPv6 validation patterns. First level validation discards irrelevant input, reading only the input that is applicable to form a valid IPv6 address, for example: A-F or a-f and 0-9 with: (colon) and. (dot) characters.
SNMP Read Community* - Enables a user-configurable community Read password that is used when issuing an SNMP command
SNMP Write Community* - Enables a user-configurable community Write password that is used when issuing an SNMP command.

IPv6 IP Address* - Shows, or use to enter an globally accessible IP address for the selected node. WaveReady Multi-Node Manager supports dual-stack addressing for the node IP address. The COM-200 must be reset in order for a change in this field to take effect.
IPv6 Addressing: IPv6 address fields are equipped with first level IPv6 validation patterns. First level validation discards irrelevant input, reading only the input that is applicable to form a valid IPv6 address, for example: A-F or a-f and 0-9 with: (colon) and. (dot) characters.

Ipv6 Subnet Mask or Prefix* - Shows, or use to enter the subnet mask or prefix for the selected node. WaveReady Multi-Node Manager supports dual-stack addressing for the node IP subnet mask or prefix. The COM-200 must be reset for a change in this field to take effect.
IPv6 Prefix: Valid format for this field is nnn, where nnn is an integer between 000 and 999. Only the digits 0-9 will be accepted, with a maximum of three characters.

IPv6 Gateway IP Address* - WaveReady Multi-Node Manager supports dual-stack addressing for the node IP gateway IP address. The COM-200 must be reset in order for a change in this field to take effect.
IPv6 Addressing: IPv6 address fields are equipped with first level IPv6 validation patterns. First level validation discards irrelevant input, reading only the input that is applicable to form a valid IPv6 address, for example: A-F or a-f and 0-9 with: (colon) and. (dot) characters.

Ethernet Auto Sensing* - Using the pull-down menu, turn Ethernet auto-sensing on or off. When off, manual setting of the hub speed for ethernet speed 10mb or 100mb and full or half duplex is possible.
Ethernet Speed* - Using the pull-down menu, select an Ethernet speed of 10 M-Bit or 100 M-Bit.
Ethernet Duplex* - Using the pull-down menu, select the duplex mode (half or full duplex) when auto sensing is turned off.
Switch Port 1/2- Using the pull-down menu, select the Switching Mode for the COM-200 Ethernet ports 1 and 2. Options are Normal and Blocked.

Switch Port 3** - Using the pull-down menu, select the switching Mode for the COM-200 Ethernet Port 3. Options are Normal, Blocked and External Shelf (used to establish communications with an external shelf unit.) Only Ethernet Port 3 supports External Shelf mode.
TL1 User Session Time out: User-configurable value for the length of time a management session will remain open without activity. Default is 999 minutes.

Force Password Change on First Login: User-configurable value to enable or disable whether a new user must enter a new (changed) password when logging in to a new node for the first time. Default is Disabled.

body.note: Changes to the fields marked with * require a communications module (COM-200) restart to take effect.
Changes to the fields marked with ** will automatically initiate a communications module restart. If the switching mode of this port is changed, a warning dialog will appear to confirm the action.
body.p: These buttons appear on the Properties panel when a node is selected:

ul.li: Refresh Shelf Inventory - Click to initiate the discovery (or re-discovery) of external shelf units, such as the WRS-051. Use to establish or re-establish communication with an external shelf unit.
Set Date & Time... - Click to set the date and time for the node
Set System ID... - Click to set the System ID for the node
Apply button - Click to submit the changes to the node.
Refresh button - Click to update the information displayed on the panel.

body.p: Use the Properties panel to do these tasks:

li.xref: Setting the System ID on page 5-13
Setting the Date and Time on page 5-17
Enabling the NTP Service on page 5-18
Alternate Management of WaveReady Nodes on page 5-30
Configuring an SNMP Agent on page 5-20

note.p: SNMP is not supported for all WaveReady systems. See the applicable Release Notes for supported hardware and software.

li.xref: Specifying an SNMP Community String on page 5-21
Enabling Ethernet Auto-Sensing Parameters on page 5-22

body.p: IPv6 addresses are 128-bit identifiers for interfaces and sets of interfaces. The valid formats for an IPv6 address are defined in RFC 4291, the Internet Society specification defining the addressing architecture of the IP Version 6 (IPv6) protocol. The document includes the IPv6 addressing model, text representations of IPv6 addresses, definition of IPv6 unicast addresses, anycast addresses, and multicast addresses, and an IPv6 node's required addresses.
The full document is available from the The Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) website at: http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4291.txt
All IPv4 and IPv6 addresses are evaluated and validated according to these criteria:

li.p: Valid characters for these addresses include : (colon), 0-9 (digits), and A-Z or a-z (alphabet) and . (dot).
An address written in IPv4 format (nnn.nnn.nnn.nnn) cannot include a-f (hexadecimal chars for IPv6) or : (colon).
IPv4 addresses will be accepted in IPv6 format, however only IPv4 addresses may include . (dot) characters, even when entered in IPv6 format
Valid IPv6 addresses can include (blank space) and : : (colon colon).
Note - : : (colon colon) indicates a unspecified IPv6 address
A maximum of four (4) . (dots) characters are allowed.
A maximum of seven (7) : (colon) characters per address are allowed; no more than two colons may be written in a series.
Example - : : : is invalid.
A maximum of eight (8) 16 bit blocks (separated by a colon) are allowed in each IPv6 address

ul.li: Example - 2001:DB8:0:0:8:800:200C:417A:333 is invalid

body.p: IPv6 or IPv4 addresses that do not meet these criteria will return an error message “Invalid IPv6 address.”

topic.title: Node Manager Support of IPv6 Addressing

body.p: WaveReady Node Manager supports dual-stack IP addressing. Addresses may be entered in IPv4 or IPv6 format.
There are some conditions and limitations to this dual-stack addressing.

section.title: Globally Accessible IP Addresses
section.p: All globally accessible IP addresses must be configured. When a node with an existing configured IPv4 address is upgraded to R4.6.6 or above, it will retain its IPv4 address. The IPv6 stack, while enabled and active, will remain empty. The IPv6 address must be configured separately.
New node installations and new node configurations can use either or both IPv4 and IPv6 addressing.

section.title: Link Local Addresses
section.p: WaveReady supports reporting of globally accessible addresses only. Link local addresses are not reported through Node Manager or TL1.

If the link local address must be determined, it can be derived from the node MAC address. To view the node’s MAC address in Node Manager, select the node in the Equipment navigation panel, then click the Inventory tab in the main window.

section.title: JWS Host Addresses
section.p: If using IPv6 addressing for the hostname in the URL for a Java Web Start launch of Node Manager, the hostname must be enclosed in square brackets.

body.p: The properties panel information fields depend on the type of equipment selected. It displays the following equipment specific properties information:

li.xref: Module-Specific Properties Panel Fields on page 2-57
Transponder/Muxponder-Specific Properties Panel Fields on page 2-60
Port-Specific Properties Panel Fields on page 2-61

body.p: For more information about configuring equipment, see Module Configuration. The following illustrations shows a typical module-specific Properties panel with module specific fields, and a port-specific Properties panel with port specific fields.

fig.title: Typical Module Specific Properties Panel (WRT-852 Selected)

body.p: Depending on the equipment selected, a properties panel will display some of the following fields:

note.p: If a WRA module is removed from the shelf, the configured module ID for that module is deleted.

ul.li: ID - Enter or edit the ID number of the module here. The ID string can be up to 60 characters. The default value is <empty>.
Case Temperature - Display only. Shows the current measured operating temperature of the selected module.
Laser Temperature - WRA-1xx/2xx module - Display only. The measured temperature of the laser.
Operating Mode - WRA-1xx/2xx module - Select the operating mode from this pull-down Menu. Options are CONSTANTGAIN or CONSTANTPOWER. Factory default is CONSTANTGAIN.
Target Gain - WRA-1xx/2xx - Enter or edit the target signal gain here. See the WaveReady Optical Amplifier Installation and User Guide for specific values.
Target Power - WRA-1xx/2xx - Enter or edit the target total output power here. See the WaveReady Optical Amplifier Installation and User Guide for specific values.

li.p: Tilt Set Point - WRA-217C and WRA-219C only - Enter or edit the optical amplifier tilt set point here. See the WaveReady 2xx Optical Amplifier Installation and User Guide for specific values.

note.p: A thorough understanding of the limitations and consequences of applying tilt to the optical amplifier is critical before modifying a tilt set point value. An incorrect tilt set point may affect the optical network performance. Please consult with JDSU before modifying the tilt set point value.

ul.li: LOS Shutdown - WRA-1xx/2xx - Select Yes or No from the pull-down menu. When enabled (Yes) the WRA turns off the pump laser when a LOS condition is detected on the input port. Default is Disabled (No).
VOA Attenuation - WRA-2xx - Display only. Displays the measured VOA attenuation in dB. Does not apply to WRA-1xx.
Signal Gain - WRA-1xx/2xx - Display only. Displays the measured Signal Gain in dB.
Pump Current - WRA-1xx/2xx - Display only. Displays the measured Pump current in mA.
Laser Status - WRA-1xx/2xx - Display only. Displays the status of the Pump Laser.
Traffic Mode - WRT-740/840/842 - Shows the current operating traffic mode of the module.
Set Traffic Mode button - WRT-740/ WRT-840/842 - Changes the Traffic mode. Values are Transponder and Regenerator.
Auto Rate Locking - WRT-840/842 - Enables or disables Automatic Rate Locking.
Manual Data Lock Rate - WRT-840/842 - Enables selection of a data rate to which the WRT-840 or WRT-842 will attempt to lock when the Auto Rate Locking option is disabled.

Number of Supervisory Links - Display only. Applies to WRT-740/760 only. Shows the number of management links currently enabled between the selected WRT-740/WRT-760/WRT-840/WRT-842-200/WRT-852 and other WRT-740/WRT-760s. At present, WRT-740/WRT-760/WRT-840/WRT-842-200/WRT-852 support only one link at a time.

Sense Monitor - Enables or disables the sense monitors on the WRT-7xx /WRT-8xxmodule. The sense input lines can be used to indicate conditions local to the module. When the sense input lines are connected and the Sense Monitor is enabled, an alarm will be generated when the sense input line is closed.
Sense Fault Description - WRT-780 /WRT-8xx/WRM-782 - Describes the current sense line monitor.
Manage Supervisory Channel button - WRT-740/WRT-760/WRT-840/WRT-842 - Click to display the Supervisory Channel Management window.
Active Path - LP-530 - Display only. Shows the currently active path: Primary or Secondary.
Mode of Operation - LP-530 - Specify the operating mode of the LP-530 here.
Auto radio button - LP-530 - Select this option to enable automatic protection switching. The Auto Switching Mode and the Revertive Switching fields are only available when Auto is selected.

Manual radio button -LP-530 - Select this option to enable manual operating mode. Automatic protection switching is disabled when the module is operating in manual mode. This can result in loss of traffic if a failure occurs on the active path.

Sense-Priority radio button - LP-530 - Select this option to enable the sense input operating mode. In this mode, switching only occurs in response to the state of the sense input relay on the backplane.
Auto Switching Mode - LP-530 - Available when Auto is selected in the Mode of Operation field. Set the module switching mode here.
Fixed radio button - LP-530 - Available when Auto switching mode is selected. Select this option to set the switching mode to absolute (Fixed).
Relative radio button - LP-530 - Available when Auto switching mode is selected. Select this option to set the switching mode to window switching (Relative). In this mode the module switches paths.

Revertive Switching - LP-530 - Available when Auto is selected for the Mode of Operation. When enabled, the module automatically switches traffic back to the primary path when the optical power returns to an acceptable level.
Yes radio button - LP-530 - Select this option to enable automatic switch-back.
No radio button - LP-530 - Select this option to disable automatic-switch-back.

li.p: Absolute Switching Level Threshold - LP-530 - Available when Auto Switching Mode is set to Fixed. Enter the optical power level (an integer in the range -5 to -35 dBm) that the module will use to determine when to switch to the alternate available path.

note.p: Window Switching mode requires a measured reference power level (RPL), and a lower window switching limit threshold (LWSLTH), to determine when to activate the switch.

ul.li: Upper Window Switching Range - LP-530 - Available when Auto Switching Mode is set to Relative. The value specified represents the range of optical input power in dB, between the Reference Power Level and the Upper Window Switching Threshold (an integer greater than 6 and less than 29 dB) that the module will use to determine when to switch to the alternate path.

Lower Window Switching Range - LP-530 - Available when Auto Switching Mode is set to Relative. This value represents the range of optical input power in dB, between the Reference Power Level and the Lower Window Switching Threshold (an integer greater than 6 and less than 29 dB) that the module uses to determine when to switch to the alternate path.

li.p: Set Reference Power Level - LP-530 - Click this button to save the current input power on each optical path as the reference power level (RPL) applied in window switching mode.

note.p: When setting the RPL, the module reads the incoming power level on both paths simultaneously. If the same power level is applied to both paths, balance the signals on the paths before clicking the Set Reference Power Level button.

body.p: Depending on the equipment selected, a properties panel will display some of the following fields:

ul.li: Traffic Mode - WRT-852 - The current Traffic mode of the module. The mode is changed by clicking the Set Traffic Mode button and entering the new value. The equipment must be taken Out-of-Service before changing the traffic mode.
Set Traffic Mode button -WRT-852 Transponder - Changes the Traffic mode.

Auto Locking Mode - WRT-780/WRT-781/WRT-852 - Enables or disables Automatic Rate Locking. If enabled, the module attempts to lock onto each supported bit rate sequentially, on both ports. If disabled, the module will lock on the user-provisioned manual lock data rate.
Manual Data Lock Rate - WRT-780/WRT-781/WRT-852 - Enables selection of a data rate to which the transponder will attempt to lock when the Auto Rate Locking option is disabled.

Expected Bit Rate - WRT-780/WRT-781/WRT-852 - Configurable only when Automatic Rate Locking Mode is enabled. An alarm will be raised if the bit rate of the incoming signal does not match the value provisioned for the expected bit rate.

Fast LOS/LOL Propagation Mode - WRT-780/WRT-781WRT-852- Should be enabled only when the transponder is deployed in a protected network where service is switched between redundant transponders by an optical layer protection switch such as a WaveReady LP-530.

fig.title: Typical Port Specific Properties Panel (Network Port Selected)

body.p: Depending on the equipment selected, a port properties panel will display some of the following fields:

ul.li: SFP Missing - Display only - Indicates whether the SFP is in place or has been removed.
Laser Disabled - Display only - Indicates whether the SFP laser is enabled or disabled
Laser Temperature - (WRT-8xx Network Port) Display only. Measured temperature of the laser.
Input Power - Display only - Shows the power level in dBm of the incoming optical signal currently being received. If no optical signal is being received this value is a large negative number.
Output Power - Display only - Shows the power level in dBm of the optical signal currently being transmitted. If no optical signal is being transmitted this value is a large negative number.
Wavelength - Display only - Shows the wavelength of the selected port.
Reach - Display only - Shows the reach or dispersion limit of the selected port.
Actual Bit Rate - Display only - Shows the actual measured bit rate (mbps) being received on the port.
Expected Bit Rate - WRT-740/760 Port - An alarm will be raised if the bit rate of the incoming signal does not match the value entered here.
Minimum Bit Rate - Display only - Shows the minimum bit rate for the SFP/XFP.
Maximum Bit Rate - Display only - Shows the maximum bit rate for the SFP/XFP.
SFP Maximum Bit Rate - (WRT-8xx Client Port) Display only. Shows the maximum bit rate of the XFP adaptor installed on the client side.

LOS Threshold —(WRA-1xx/2xx Rx Port) Enter or edit the value here. This is the power value, in dBm, at which a LOS alarm will be generated. See the WaveReady Optical Amplifier Installation and User Guide for specific values.
