LOS Hysteresis —(WRA-1xx/2xx Rx Port) Enter or edit the value here. This is the difference, in dB, between the threshold at which a LOS alarm is raised and the threshold at which it is cleared. See the WaveReady Optical Amplifier Installation and User Guide for specific values.

Input Degrade Threshold —(WRA-1xx/2xx Rx Port) Enter or edit the value here. This is the power value, in dBm, at which a Signal Degrade alarm is generated. See the WaveReady Optical Amplifier Installation and User Guide for specific values.

Input Degrade Hysteresis —(WRA-1xx/2xx Rx Port) Enter or edit the value here. This is the difference, in dB, between the threshold at which a Signal Degrade alarm is raised and the value at which it is cleared. See the WaveReady Optical Amplifier Installation and User Guide for specific values.

LOO Threshold —(WRA-1xx/2xx Tx Port) Enter or edit the value here. This is the power value in dBm, at which a LOO alarm will be generated. See the WaveReady Optical Amplifier Installation and User Guide for specific values.
LOO Hysteresis —(WRA-1xx/2xx Tx Port) Enter or edit the value here. This is the difference, in dB, between the threshold at which an LOO alarm is raised and the threshold at which it is cleared.

Output Degrade Threshold —(WRA-1xx/2xx Tx Port) Enter or edit the value here. This is the power value, in dBm, at which a Signal Degrade alarm is generated. See the WaveReady Optical Amplifier Installation and User Guide for specific values.

Output Degrade Hysteresis —(WRA-1xx/2xx Tx Port) Enter or edit the value here. This is the difference, in dB, between the threshold at which a Signal Degrade alarm is raised and the value at which it is cleared.
SFP Vendor - Display only - Shows the vendor of the SFP/XFP adaptor installed on the client side.
SFP Part Number - Display only - Shows the part number of the SFP/XFP.
SFP Serial Number - Display only - Shows the serial number of the SFP/XFP.
SFP Temperature - Display only - Shows the measured internal temperature in degrees C of the SFP.
SFP Laser Bias Current - Display only - Shows the measured bias current that is being applied to the laser diode within the specified SFP.
Input Status - WRT-740/760 Client Port - Display only. Shows the state of the client signal: on (present) off (no signal).
Input Power - WRT-740/760 Client Port - Display only. Shows the input power of the port.
Output Status - WRT-740/760 Client Port - Display only. Shows the laser status of the selected port: On or Off.
Output Power - WRT-740/760 Client Port - Display only. Shows the output power of the port.
Output Power - WRA-1xx/2xx Tx Port - Display Only. This is the total optical power level measured on the output port, without ASE compensation.
Signal Output Power - WRA-1xx/2xx Tx Port - Display Only. This is the optical power level measured on the output port.
On Client Port LOS - WRT-740/760 Network Port - Determines the action of the network-side laser in the event of a loss of signal (LOS) on the client side:
Squelch radio button - WRT-740/760 Network Port - When selected, will disable the data but keep the laser turned on. This allows the modules to maintain the supervisory channel, if one is enabled.

Turn Off Laser radio button - WRT-740/760 Network Port - When selected, will turn off the network-side laser in the event a loss of signal is detected on the client side. Used if the WRT-740/WRT-760 is not paired with another WRT-740/WRT-760.
Manage Supervisory Channel button - WRT-740/760 Network Port - Click to display the Supervisory Channel Management window.
Actual RxDT - WRT-8xx Network Port - Display only. The actual receiver decision threshold in percentage.

Manual RxDT - WRT-8xx Network Port - The user-configured receiver decision threshold used when RxDT Optimization Mode is set to Manual. The RxDT Optimization Mode must be set to Manual for the module to use the Manual RxDT value.

Optimal Back-to-Back RxDT - WRT-8xx Network Port- Display Only. Shows the optimal RxDT value to configure for the Manual RxDT option, when operating the WRT-842-200 in back-to-back mode (0 ps/nm). The RxDT Optimization Mode must be set to Manual for the module to use the Manual RxDT value.

RxDT Optimization Mode - WRT-8xx Network Port- This is the Receiver Decision Threshold Optimization Mode. Options are Manual or Automatic. In Manual RxDT mode, the module attempts to lock onto the user-configured Manual RxDT rate. In Auto RxDT mode the RxDT is set automatically.
Manage Supervisory Channel button - WRT-8xx Network Port - Click to display the Supervisory Channel Management window.
Input Power - LP-530 - Enter the optical power measured on either the working or protect ports here.
Reference Power Level - LP-530 - Enter the baseline optical power level on the optical port (an integer greater than or equal to -29 dBm and less than or equal to -6dBm) here.

Upper Window Switching Threshold - LP-530 port - Enter the upper optical input power threshold (an integer less than or equal to 0) that the module uses to determine when to switch to the alternate path here.
Lower Window Switching Threshold - LP-530 port - Enter the lower optical input power threshold (an integer greater than 6) used by the module to determine when to switch to the alternate path here.

body.p: Use the Properties panel to do these tasks:

li.xref: Verifying Equipment Operating State on page 6-9
Setting the Expected Bit Rate on page 6-18
Enabling the Sense Fault Monitor on page 6-19
Specifying a Sense Fault Description on page 6-20
Setting the Traffic Mode on page 6-22
Setting Manual Data Lock Rate on page 6-23
Enabling Automatic Rate Locking on page 6-25
Enabling WRT-780/852/WRM-782 Fast Fault Propagation on page 6-26
Setting the WRT-842/WRT-852 Wavelength on page 6-27
Setting the WRT-842 RxDT Optimization Mode on page 6-28
Specifying the WRT-842 Manual RxDT on page 6-30
Setting Amplifier Module Operating Parameters on page 6-34
Setting RX Port Parameters on page 6-36
Setting TX Port Parameters on page 6-37
Setting the LP-530 Operating Mode on page 6-44
Setting the LP-530 Switching Mode on page 6-45
Enabling or Disabling the LP-530 Revertive Mode on page 6-46
Setting LP-530 Absolute Switching Level Threshold on page 6-47
Setting the LP-530 Window Switching Range on page 6-47
Setting the LP-530 Window Switching Range on page 6-47

body.p: The Properties panel information fields depend on the type of equipment selected. When an external shelf or unit, such as the WRS-051 is selected, it displays the external-shelf specific properties.
The WRS-051 unit Properties page displays these fields:

ul.li: Unit ID - An optional user-specified module identifier. The ID string can be up to 60 characters. The default value is <empty>.
Case Temperature - Display only. Shows the current measured operating temperature of the selected WRS-051 case.

Sense Monitor - Enables or disables the sense monitors on the WRS-051 module. The sense input lines can be used to indicate conditions local to the module. When the sense input lines are connected and the Sense Monitor is enabled, an alarm will be generated when the sense input line is closed.

note.p: The Wavelength Management window is also accessible from the properties panel.

body.p: The WRS-051 common port Properties page displays these fields:

ul.li: Input Power - Display only. The power level, in dBm, of the optical signal currently being received. When no optical signal is being received this value will be a large negative floating-point number.

Output Power - Display only. This is the power level, in dBm, of the optical signal currently being transmitted. When no optical signal is being transmitted this value will be a large negative floating-point number.

body.p: The WRS-051 optical channels Properties page displays these fields:

ul.li: Wavelength - Display only. Shows the wavelength of the selected channel.
Channel ID - An optional user-specified identifier. The ID string can be up to 60 characters. The default value is <empty>
Power Target - If the optical channel is unblocked, this field specifies the transmit channel power on the common port.
Actual Power - Display only. The actual output power of the optical channel.
Attentuation - Display only. The attenuation in dB of the specified channel. When no optical signal is present, or the channel is Out-of-Service, this value will be a large number or “inf.”
Maximum Possible Output Power - Display only.
Minimum Recommended Output Power - Display only.

Input Port - Add/Drop port of the specified optical channel. A channel may only be active or In-Service on one port at a time. The optical connection must be taken Out-of-Service before changing the input port.

body.p: Use this window to manage and configure optical channel connections for the WRS-051.
Access the Wavelength Management window by selecting an WRS-051 optical channel in the Explorer panel and then:

ul.li: Open the Properties Panel and click the Wavelength Manager button in the lower right hand corner.
Select Configuration > Configure Properties to open the Channel Properties window and click the Wavelength Manager button in the lower right hand corner.

From the Chassis Graphic, double-click the “E” on the third (bottom-most) Ethernet port of the COM-200 graphic to open the Chassis Graphic for External Shelf view. Then double-click the Wavelength Manager icon in the upper center of the WRS-051 graphic.

body.p: The Wavelength Management window contains these components:

The channel monitor area displays each 100 GHz optical channel as a “candlestick”, showing the current operating conditions of each channel. With the exception of a selection check-box, this display area is not user-configurable.
The channel monitor area displays the following information about each optical channel (starting from the bottom of the candlestick):

ul.li: Channel number - Display only. Indicates the channel number.
Selection check box - Selects the optical channel for configuration in the Channel Details area.

Maintenance state indicator - Display only. Indicates the state of the optical channel.
Red - critical alarm is present
Orange - major alarm is present
Yellow - minor alarm is present
Green - normal operation
Gray - Out-of-Service
Input port number - Display only. Indicates the add/drop port currently serving the optical channel.
Minimum recommended output power level indicator (yellow bar) - Display only.
Actual power level indicator (green column) - Display only.
Power target indicator (blue arrowhead) - Display only.
Maximum possible output power level indicator (green bar) - Display only.

body.p: The channel detail area presents the same information as the channel monitor area. Use the fields and pull-down menus in this area to monitor, manage and configure the optical channels:

ul.li: Wavelength - Display only. Shows the wavelength of the selected channel.
Channel ID - Enter an optional user-specified identifier here. The ID string can be up to 60 characters. The default value is <empty>

Power Target - If the optical channel is unblocked, this field specifies the transmit channel power on the common port. Use this field to set the power target used to power balance the WRS-051 output.
Actual Power - Display only. The actual output power of the optical channel.
Attentuation - Display only. The attenuation in dB of the specified channel. When no optical signal is present, or the channel is Out-of-Service, this value will be a large number or “inf.”
Maximum Possible Output Power - Display only.
Minimum Recommended Output Power - Display only.

Input Port - Add/Drop port of the specified optical channel. A channel may only be active or In-Service on one port at a time. The Optical Connection must be taken Out-of-Service before changing the input port.
Maintenance State - Use this pull-down menu to change the state of the selected optical channel before switching the optical channel between input ports.

body.p: To apply any changes made in the Channel Details area, click the Apply button. To return to the original settings without applying any changes, click the Refresh button.
The Wavelength Manager window also contains these general management buttons:

ul.li: Auto In-Service - Initiates the Auto-Tune-up (Learn) function. Auto In-Service should only be clicked once. Subsequent clicks will be ignored as the WRS-051 Auto Tune-Up function attempts to bring out of service (OOS) channels into service (IS). This does not affect traffic on channels already in-service (IS) in the target WRS-051, but it could affect traffic on downstream channels.Not to be confused with Refresh which only updates the display of the current operating state of channels. Since the two buttons are side-by-side, a confirmation dialog will appear when the Auto In-Service button is clicked to confirm the action.
Refresh - Manually refreshes the display. The display automatically updates, or refreshes itself, when any alarms for a channel occurs.
Close - Close the Wavelength Manager window.
Help - Open the WaveReady Node Manager On-line Help system.

body.p: Node Manager provides three other windows for properties management related information. Use these windows to retrieve information or set certain configuration settings (such as the supervisory channel (EMC or SVC)) for module operations.
These windows are:

li.xref: Supervisory Channel Management window on page 2-70
Facilities Protection Management window on page 2-73
The Wavelength Management Window on page 2-67

body.p: Use this window to view information about the Supervisory Channel (SVC)) configuration and status, or to enable and disable SVC for the WRT-740, WRT-760, WRT-840, WRT-842-200 or WRT-852 modules. See Enabling a Supervisory Channel on page 6-31.

topic.title: Accessing the Supervisory Channel Management window

body.p: After selecting the equipment from the Explorer panel, access the Supervisory Channel Management window in one of these ways:

ul.li: From the Properties panel (with WRT-740, WRT-760, WRT-840, WRT-842-200 or WRT-852 selected), click the Manage Supervisory Channel button.
From the main window menus, select Configuration > Manage Supervisory Channel.
From the chassis graphic, right-click and select Supervisory Channel Management from the pop-up menu.

topic.title: The Supervisory Channel Management window components

body.p: Some or all of the following fields and options are displayed on the Supervisory Channel Management window:

ul.li:
Primary State - Display only. Shows the current service condition of the supervisory channel. There are two possible states:
In Service
Out Of Service

Primary State Qualifier - Display only. Provides additional information about the primary state of the supervisory channel.
When the SVC is in-service, the field shows if the SVC is wholly, or only partially in-service. These qualifiers are associated with the in-service state: “Normal”
When a module is out-of-service, the field indicates if the module is out-of-service as the result of a user action, a fault in the equipment, or the result of some event. These qualifiers are associated with the out-of-service state: “Autonomous”, “Management”

Secondary State - Display only. Shows additional information about the primary and primary state qualifiers. For example, the secondary state can indicate the type of, and/or the reason, for the user action or the event that occurred. These are the possible secondary states:
Facility Failure - An LOS or LOL condition exists
Protocol Failure - A protocol failure may occur when either end of the link (the modules themselves, or the corresponding COM-200s) are running different software versions (for example, if one end has been upgraded and the other has not). A protocol failure can also occur during signal degrade conditions that are not significant enough to cause LOS/LOL failure conditions

note.p: It is possible for the equipment to have more than one secondary state at a time.

ul.li: SVC (FSK) Version - Display only. Shows the version of the SVC protocol that the supervisory channel is using.
SVC (FSK) Speed - Display only. Shows the baud rate at which the supervisory channel is operating.
Physical Port in Use - Display only. Shows the network port that the supervisory channel is using.
Supervisory Channel Enabled - Display only. Shows the current state of the supervisory channel.

On Client/Network Out of Service - Controls whether or not the SVC will go autonomously out of service when the supporting network port changes to OOS state.
If Disable is selected, the SVC will autonomously go out of service when the supporting network port changes to OOS state.
If No Effect is selected, the SVC will NOT change to OOS when the supporting network port changes to OOS state.

Enable Supervisory Channel / Disable Supervisory Channel button - Click to enable or disable the supervisory channel. The label that appears on this button depends on the current state of the Supervisory Channel.
If the supervisory channel is enabled, the button displays the option to Disable Supervisory Channel.
If the supervisory channel is disabled, the button displays the option to Enable Supervisory Channel.

body.p: Use this window to manage protection groups and designate working and protection ports for WRT-760 modules.

topic.title: Accessing the Facility Protection Management window

body.p: Access the Facility Protection Management window by selecting a WRT760 in the Explorer panel and then:

ul.li: Selecting Configuration > Manage Facility Protection from the top menu.
From the Chassis Graphic, right-clicking on the WRT760 and select Facility Protection Management from the pop-up menu

topic.title: The Facility Protection Management window components:

body.p: The following fields and options are displayed on the Facility Protection Management window:

ul.li: Protection Group Name - The user-assigned name for the protection group.
Working Interface - Display only The network port designated as the working port.
Protecting Interface - Display only The network port designated as the protection port.
Revertive Mode - The current status of the revertive mode feature.
Revertive Time out - The number of seconds the module should “wait to restore” (WTR) the working port.
Create button - Click to create a facility protection group. Enabled only if a facility protection group is not present.
Apply button - Click to apply all changes.
Delete button - Click to delete a facility protection group.
Working Status button - Click to open the Status & Maintenance window for the working port, which gives the current operating status of that port.
Protecting Status button - Click to open the Status & Maintenance window for the protection port, which gives the current operating status of that port.
Refresh button - Click to refresh the information displayed in the window.
Close button - Click to close the window.

li.xref: Creating a WRT-760 Facility Protection Group on page 6-38
Deleting a WRT-760 Facility Protection Group on page 6-39
Enabling or Disabling WRT-760 Revertive Mode on page 6-40
Setting WRT-760 Revertive Time-Out on page 6-41

body.p: The Chassis Graphic Properties window contains the same components as the Properties Panel, with the addition of a Close button at the bottom right hand corner.
Access the Chassis Graphic Properties window by:

li.p: Select a node from the Explorer panel.
Select View > Chassis Graphic to display the chassis graphic for the node.
Right-click on an equipment graphic (such as a module or port) in the chassis graphic and select Properties from the pop-up menu.

body.p: Use the buttons and display area in this window to review the element properties, then return to the Chassis Graphic by clicking the Close button.

This panel retrieves and displays a list of events for selected equipment, and is available for nodes and modules. Use this panel to display the Events Log for the selected equipment. Use buttons in this panel to filter events, and save this information.
body.note: Detailed procedures to configure and manage events are described in Alarms and Performance Statistics Management on page 7-1
body.p: This section includes information about:

li.xref: Accessing the Events Log Panel or Window on page 2-75
The Events Log Panel on page 2-75
The Chassis Graphic Events Window on page 2-77

topic.title: Accessing the Events Log Panel or Window

body.p: Select a node component, then access the Events Log by:

ul.li: Clicking the Events Log tab at the top of the Information panel
Selecting Administration > View Events Log from the top menu.
Right-clicking and select Events Log from the pop-up menu in the Chassis Graphic.

body.p: The Events Log panel contains these components.

The Log Entries area contains seven columns. The order of the columns can be re-arranged to suit individual users. Rearrange the columns by dragging a column heading bar to a new position. Sort the list by ascending or descending order by clicking on the column header.
The columns have the following headings:

ul.li: Date - Display only. Shows the timestamp indicating when the event occurred.
Location - Display only. Shows the location (shelf, slot number) of the equipment where the event occurred.
Severity - Display only. Shows the severity of the event: critical, major, minor, (not alarmed), (not reported).
Event - Display only. Shows a brief description of the event.
Description - Display only. Shows the event type.
State - Display only. Shows the state associated with the event: standing or transient.
Affecting - Display only. Shows if the event affected service with YES or NO.

body.p: Use the check box and button in this area to filter the events displayed in the list using a time filter.
The show area contains the following fields and options:

ul.li: Time Filter check box - Check this box to open the Event Log Time Filter window.
Time Filter button - Click to open the Event Log Time Filter window to set the criteria to limit the events displayed to those that occurred during the specified time period.
Refresh button - Click to update the information displayed on the panel.
Save As button - Click to save the Events Log as either a comma separated values (CSV) or XML file.

body.p: The Chassis Graphics Events window contains the same components as the The Events Log Panel on page 2-75, with the addition of a Close button at the bottom right hand corner.
Access the Chassis Graphic Events window by:

li.p: Select a node from the Explorer panel.
Select View > Chassis Graphic to display the chassis graphic for the node.
Right-click on an equipment graphic (such as a module or port) in the chassis graphic and select Events from the pop-up menu.

body.p: Use the buttons and display area in this window to review the events associated with the selected element, then return to the Chassis Graphic by clicking the Close button.

This panel retrieves and displays a list of performance statistics for selected equipment. Currently performance statistics are returned for both the client and network ports of the WRT-852 only, when the module is operating in one of the “...with FEC” traffic modes.
The tab will be grayed-out for all other WRT-852 traffic modes, and other modules; the panel will show the message “This panel is unavailable.”
Use the buttons in this panel to start the retrieval, stop the retrieval, clear the previously collected statistics before re-starting the counter for another test, and save this information.
body.note: Detailed procedures to use the performance statistics panel to collect, monitor and review performance statistics are described in Alarms and Performance Statistics Management on page 7-1.
body.p: This section includes information about:

li.xref: Accessing the Performance Panel or Window on page 2-78
The Performance Panel on page 2-78
The Chassis Graphic Performance Window on page 2-81

topic.title: Accessing the Performance Panel or Window

body.p: Select a port, then access the Performance statistics by:

ul.li: Clicking the Performance tab at the top of the Information panel to display the Performance panel, or
Right-clicking on a port, then selecting Performance from the pop-up menu in the Chassis Graphic to display the Performance window.

body.p: The Performance panel contains these components.

The Performance statistics entries area contains four columns. The order of the columns can be re-arranged to suit individual users. Rearrange the columns by dragging a column heading bar to a new position. Resize the columns by dragging the break between columns. Sort the list by ascending or descending order by clicking on the column header.
The columns have the following headings:

ul.li: Entity - Display only. Shows the AID (shelf-slot number-port number) of the monitored node component.
Modifier - Display only. Shows the traffic protocol of the monitored node component.
Monitor - Display only. Lists the monitor types; the specific performance being monitored.

Current - Display only. Reports the number of Section Frame Counts for each protocol and the associated instances of error for each parameter. Counters representing error rates greater than 0 are highlighted in yellow.

body.p: Performance statistics collection is currently supported for OTU2, OC192 and 10GIGE.

The check boxes in the Secondary Command (SCCM) area indicate which of three applicable traffic protocols (OTU2, OC192 and 10GIGE) are in use by the selected port. These check boxes are for information only; they are grayed out and not user-configurable.

The performance statistics reported in the Performance statistics entries area are collected and displayed for all applicable protocols. These statistics are grouped by protocol in the Modifier column.

note.p: It is useful to note that the counts of a particular monitor type may be different between protocols.

body.p: There are four Performance Counter management buttons.

ul.li: Start/Stop button - Click Start to begin collecting performance statistics for all the traffic protocols indicated in the Secondary Command area. Click Stop to stop the collection and close the collection bins. The statistics displayed will automatically refresh depending on the refresh frequency selected in the Performance statistics management area.

li.p: Clear Current button - Click Clear Current to:

ol.li: clear (empty) the monitor type collection bins of the currently collected statistics,
immediately begin collecting statistics again, and
automatically refresh the information display with the new performance statistics.

note.p: This feature is useful when testing a network, since collection of new statistics begins immediately, giving an accurate count of any problems still remaining.

ul.li: Refresh button - Click the Refresh button to update the information displayed on the panel.
Save As button - Click to save the Performance Stats as either a comma separated values (CSV) or XML file.

body.p: There are two Performance statistics management tools.

ul.li: Refresh - Use this pull-down menu to select the auto-refreshing frequency of the performance statistics.
Details - Display only. Shows the elapsed counter time of the performance statistics for the monitor type.

body.p: The Chassis Graphic Performance window contains the same components as the The Performance Panel on page 2-78, with the addition of a Close button at the bottom right hand corner.
Access the Chassis Graphic Performance window by:

li.p: Select a node from the Explorer panel.
Select View > Chassis Graphic to display the chassis graphic for the node.
Right-click on an equipment graphic (such as an applicable module or port) in the chassis graphic and select Performance from the pop-up menu.

body.p: Use the buttons and display area in this window to review the performance statistics, then return to the Chassis Graphic by clicking the Close button.

topic.title: Back up and Restore Module Configuration

body.p: The Node Manager Back up and Restore feature avoids re-provisioning data when replacing a module.
This section provides an overview of using the Backup window to back up module configuration data for the node, and the Restore window to restore data for individual modules or for the entire node.

For detailed information about creating backup files and restoring module configuration, see Backing Up Equipment Configuration Data on page 5-33, Retrieving a Backup File on page 5-35 and Restoring Configuration Data from a Backup File on page 5-36 in Node Level Configuration and Management on page 5-1.

note.p: These features are intended to be used for commissioning and not as a backup utility to create backups at routine intervals.
The LightAmp and BrightAmp modules do not support backup and restore.

The Backup and Restore features use FTP. For FTP to work properly and the BAR to succeed, the computer used to initiate the Backup and Restore must have direct IP connectivity - not Supervisory Management Channel (SVC/EMC) connectivity - to the COM-200 of the NE. An SNE without an Ethernet connection to its COM-200 will not be able to backup and restore configuration data.

body.p: This section covers the following topics:

li.xref: Accessing the Backup and Restore Windows on page 2-82
The Backup and Restore window components on page 2-82
Related tasks on page 2-84

topic.title: Accessing the Backup and Restore Windows

body.p: To access the Backup and Restore windows, select Configuration > Backup or Restore from the top menu.

topic.title: The Backup and Restore window components

body.p: The following fields and options are displayed on the Backup window:

ul.li: Save In panel - Enables specifying a directory in which to store a backup file.
Retrieve Backup Files Only - Allows retrieving the current back up file from the NE and store it in a specified directory, without running a backup.
Results - The Results panel shows the modules that were successfully backed up after a backup completes.
Start Button - Starts the Backup using the specified options.

image.href: .\graphics\Restore window, restore status not backed up.jpg

body.p: The following fields and options are displayed on the Restore window:

ul.li: File panel - Use this field to select a backup file from which to restore the configuration of the module or modules specified in the Targets area.

Target Modules - Use this area to view information about the modules installed in the shelf, including the module type, software release version, backup type, backup release, and restorable status. Select a module or group of modules to restore whose restorable status is indicated as OK.
Results - Shows the module or modules the system attempted to restore and the status of the data restoration.
Start Button - Starts the Restore using the specified options.

body.p: Use the Backup window to do these tasks:

li.xref: Backing Up Equipment Configuration Data on page 5-33
Retrieving a Backup File on page 5-35

body.p: Use the Restore window to do these tasks:

li.xref: Restoring Configuration Data from a Backup File on page 5-36

body.p: The Node Manager chassis graphic window is one of two windows that display automatically when the application launches and connects to a WaveReady system node. (The second is the Node Manager Main window and Panel view.) Configuring and managing the node can be carried out using either window.
To access the chassis graphic view at any time, select Configuration > View Chassis Graphic from the application menu bar.

note.p: If a Node Manager session is left open and inactive for more than 25 minutes, the application will “time out.”

body.p: This section includes the following topics:

li.xref: Overview of the Chassis Graphics on page 2-85
The WR3100 Chassis Graphic on page 2-86
The WR3500F / WR3500F-HP Chassis Graphic on page 2-87
Configuring Equipment from the Chassis View on page 2-88
Remote Management with the Chassis Graphic window on page 2-89
The External Shelf Chassis Graphic on page 2-92
Accessing an External Shelf or Unit on page 2-93
Configuring Equipment from the External Shelf View on page 2-94
Accessing the Wavelength Manager window on page 2-95

body.p: The chassis graphic windows provide a pictorial display of the physical shelf or shelves, all its installed modules and any external shelves or units.

note.p: A resolution of 800x600 will not display the full chassis graphic. Use a resolution of 1024x768 to view the chassis graphic in full.

body.p: The chassis view clearly shows this information:

ul.li: Occupied slots
Type of module occupying a slot
Unoccupied slots (the backplane is visible)
Unknown modules (the COM-200 is unable to determine the module type)
Un-managed modules (a module that is physically installed but unable to communicate with the COM-200.)

body.p: The basic chassis graphic window shows modules installed in the slots of the shelf. Empty shelves are identified by a label “Empty Shelf.”
Moving the cursor over each module brings up a tool tip identifying the module type.

Each module's current alarm status is shown by borders. When an alarm is raised, a red, orange or yellow border appears around each module (and port, if applicable) indicating the location and severity of the alarm.
In addition, small active alarm summary banners display on the chassis graphic, showing the total number of alarms raised by each module and for the whole shelf.
Node Manager automatically updates this alarm information on the chassis graphic whenever it receives notification that a new alarm is raised, or an active alarm is cleared.
To view detailed information about the alarms raised by a module or port, right-click on the module to open the popup menu and choose Alarms.

fig.title: Sample WR3100 Shelf Chassis Graphic view

body.p: The WaveReady 3100 shelf is a two-slot, 1-U high, rack-mount shelf suited to remote terminal and standalone network applications.

A single WaveReady 3100 shelf accommodates two WaveReady series modules. Three shelves can be interconnected, increasing capacity to six modules (as shown above): five to provide network support, and one COM-200 communications module to manage them, creating a single logical network element.
For more information about the WaveReady 3100, see the WaveReady WR3100 Shelf Installation and User Guide.

fig.title: Sample WR3500F Shelf Chassis Graphic view

body.p: The fourteen slot WR3500F and WR3500F-HP shelves provide mounting for up to 13 transport modules. The fourteenth (left-most) slot houses a COM-200 controller module installed in the shelf to support a variety of network applications.
The WR3500F and WR3500F-HP shelves, in combination with the COM-200, provide power and alarm monitoring for all WaveReady modules mounted in the unit.
The chassis graphic displays, but does not offer any way to manage, external connectors on the front of the WR3500F and WR3500F-HP shelves and a RS-232 connector on the front of the COM-200.

topic.title: Configuring Equipment from the Chassis View

section.title: Purpose
section.p: A chassis graphic window provides a real-time view of the shelf configuration, and direct management of the shelf equipment.
Follow these steps to provision equipment from the chassis view.

section.title: Requirements
section.p: This procedure has no special requirements.

section.title: Precautions
section.p: This procedure has no special precautions.

step.cmd: Select Configuration > View Chassis Graphic from the top menu to launch the chassis view.
Right-click a module, the transponder, muxponder or port on a module, or the remote module icon and right-click.
On the popup menu, click the menu item that matches the tab named in a step from The Information Panels and Related Windows on page 2-30.
Double-click on a module or port to open the Properties panel for that module or port.

info.p: A menu option is disabled (grayed out) if it is not applicable to the selected equipment.

fig.title: Sample pop-up menu from Chassis Graphic view

topic.title: Remote Management with the Chassis Graphic window

body.p: A remote node or module is one installed in a remote shelf; a COM-200 may or may not be present in the remote shelf.

A remote node may be managed via an Ethernet connection from the front plane of the COM-200 using Copper SFPs to convert signals to C/DWDM wavelengths and multiplexing them with line data channels between a pair of WRT-780s. The remote COM-200 will appear as another addressable entity on the network as long as the optical path is available.

A remote module may also be managed via the Supervisory Channel (SVC) of a paired module on the shelf with a COM-200 installed. See the appropriate module documentation for information about the relationship between traffic mode and SVCs.

section.title: Purpose
section.p: The chassis graphic includes an icon to show the status of remote modules (WRT-740/WRT-760/WRT-840/WRT-842-200/WRT-852) that are connected over the SVC. The icon shows the alarm status of the far-end equipment, and enables the management of that equipment.
Use this procedure to access the remote module to manage or configure it.

note.p: Remote Modules can be identified by their AID which, in the Explorer panel view, includes an “F”.

section.title: Requirements
section.p: This procedure has no special requirements.

section.title: Precautions
section.p: This procedure has no special precautions.

step.cmd: In the Chassis Graphic view, locate the remote module icon.
Right-click on the remote module to open a pop-up menu of configuration and management options.
On the pop-up menu, click the required menu item. For detailed information about these menu items and related operations, see The Information Panels and Related Windows on page 2-30.
Double-click on the icon to open a full-size, fully manageable view of the remote module.
Then double-click on a module or port to open the Properties window for that module or port.

info.p: A menu option is disabled (grayed out) if it is not applicable to the selected equipment.

step.cmd: Configure the module as required and click Apply to apply the changes.

info.p: The following illustration shows a Far-end Equipment icon and dialog.

fig.title: Icon and Management Window for Far-end Equipment
Sample External Shelf Chassis Graphic view

body.p: Some WaveReady units, such as the WRS-051, are managed as extensions to a WaveReady shelf-based Network Element (NE) or node where a COM-200 is installed.
To control these external units, the communication plane of the COM-200 is extended from the confines of the WaveReady shelf to the ROADM units by configuring it to operate in EXTERNAL_CONTROL mode.

In EXTERNAL_CONTROL mode, the bottom RJ45 port is dedicated to communicating with a COM-200. The discovery of external units is done automatically, without the need for any further provisioning information. Heartbeats are sent every 10 seconds from the COM-200 to detect any failures in the link.

In the Chassis Graphic, the third (bottom-most) Ethernet port of a COM-200 displays an “E” to indicate that the COM-200 is configured to External Control mode and is physically connected to an external unit.
The discovered WRS-051 or other unit is then shown as a subtending shelf in the Node Manager Explorer panel and chassis graphics.

topic.title: Accessing an External Shelf or Unit

body.p: A external shelf graphic window provides a real-time view of the unit configuration, and direct management of the unit equipment.

section.title: Purpose
section.p: Follow these steps to access the external shelf view from the chassis view.

section.title: Requirements
section.p: This procedure has no special requirements.

section.title: Precautions
section.p: This procedure has no special precautions.

step.cmd: Select Configuration > View Chassis Graphic from the top menu to launch the WR3500F / WR3500F-HP chassis view.
Double-click the “E” displayed on the bottom-most port of the COM-200 icon. The External Shelf Graphic displays.

info.p: The following illustration shows a sample External Shelf Graphic.

topic.title: Configuring Equipment from the External Shelf View

body.p: An external shelf graphic window provides a real-time view of the unit configuration, and direct management of the shelf equipment.

section.title: Purpose
section.p: Follow these steps to provision equipment from the external shelf view.

section.title: Requirements
section.p: This procedure has no special requirements.

section.title: Precautions
section.p: This procedure has no special precautions.

step.cmd: Follow the previous procedure to launch the external shelf view.
Right-click the unit, or a port on the unit. A popup menu appears.
On the popup menu, click the required menu item. For detailed information about these menu items and related operations, see The Information Panels and Related Windows on page 2-30.
Double-click on a module or port to open the Properties window for that module or port.

info.p: A menu option is disabled (grayed out) if it is not applicable to the selected equipment.
The following illustration shows an example of an External Shelf view pop-up menu.

fig.title: Sample pop-up menu from External Shelf view

body.p: The Wavelength Manager window provides a real-time view of the wavelength configuration, and direct management of the optical channels.

section.title: Purpose
section.p: Follow these steps to access the wavelength manager from the external shelf view.

section.title: Requirements
section.p: This procedure has no special requirements.

section.title: Precautions
section.p: This procedure has no special precautions.

step.cmd: Access the external shelf graphic view as described in the previous procedures.
From the external shelf graphic view:

substep.cmd: Right-click on the External Shelf Graphic and select Wavelength Manager from the pop-up list that appears. The Wavelength Manager window opens.
Double-click the Wavelength Manager Panel icon, located at the center top of the external shelf graphic. The Wavelength Manager window displays.

step.cmd: Hold the cursor over a channel candlestick to display a tool tip for that channel.

info.p: For detailed information about configuring and managing the optical channels, see the WRS-051 Installation and User Guide.
The following illustration shows an example of a Wavelength Manager window with tool tip.
